Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in addition, all but one member agreed to replace the date-based guidance with economic thresholds indicating that the exceptionally low range for the federal funds rate would remain appropriate at least as long as the unemployment rate remains above 6½ percent, inflation between one and two years ahead is projected to be no more than a half percentage point above the committee's longer-run goal, and longer-term inflation expectations continue to be well anchored.\n increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: participants generally expected that core inflation would edge lower over the next two years, reflecting a slight easing of pressures on resources, well-anchored inflation expectations, and the waning of temporary factors that had boosted prices last year and early this year.\n "label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence expects core inflation to edge lower, indicating a decrease in inflationary pressures, which is a dovish stance."

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. administered rates passed through to money market instruments.\n                "}]

Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. become less adverse than earlier in the year.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: some participants pointed to reports from contacts that firms could not as easily pass on price increases to consumers or were making less frequent price adjustments than they had in recent years.\n                "}]

2025-05-04 00:06:13,917 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Federal Reserve System\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: exports of industrial supplies and consumer goods also moved up smartly in september.\n                "}]
2025-05-04 00:06:13,917 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence only mentions an increase in exports without providing any information about its impact on inflation, employment, or monetary policy, making it neutral."

productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: votes for this action: messrs. greenspan, mcdonough, ferguson, gramlich, hoenig, jordan, kelley, mcteer, meyer, and mses.\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, yields remained high even after these announcements and moved up subsequently, notwithstanding the ecb's purchases of government debt.\n                "}]

\\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: vacancy rates continued to rise, property prices fell further, and, as indicated by the july senior loan officer opinion survey, financing for nonresidential construction projects became even tighter.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. appeared to have slowed.\n                "}]

Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} & When the dollar depreciates. & When the dollar appreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & When oil/energy prices increase, when house prices increase. & When oil/energy prices decrease, when house prices decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & When the US trade deficit increases. & When the US trade deficit decreases. & When relating to a foreign nation's economic or trade policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Fed Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Fed expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & Fed expects subpar inflation, Fed expecting disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, M2 increases, increased demand for loans. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth.” & When the stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability.” & Use of phrases “mixed,” “moderate,” “reaffirmed.” & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Corporate Bond} & When issuance increases. & When issuance decreases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When productivity or unemployment decreases. & When productivity or unemployment increases. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:fomc_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: a few participants attributed the recent equity price appreciation to expectations for Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{fomc}{eight} Economic Status, Dollar Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, corporate bond, and Labor. \n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Dollar Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as appreciation or depreciation of value of the United States Dollar on the Foreign Exchange Market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to changes in prices of real estate, energy commodities, or energy sector as a whole.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between the United States and a foreign country. If not discussing the United States we label neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{Fed Expectations/Actions/Assets}: A sentence that discusses changes in the Fed yields, bond value, reserves, or any other financial asset value.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses impact to the money supply or changes in demand.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that contains key word or phrase that would classify it squarely into one of the three label classes, based upon its frequent usage and meaning among particular label classes.\n    \\item \\emph{Corporate Bond}: A sentence that relates to corporate bond issuance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to changes in labor productivity.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The Committee then turned to a discussion of the economic and financial outlook, the ranges for the growth of money and debt in 1996, and the implementation of monetary policy over the intermeeting period ahead.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Economic status is only mentioned without diving deeper into increases or decreases in inflation and/or unemployment rate.\n    \n    \\item ``To support the Committee’s decision to raise the target range for the federal funds rate, the Board of Governors voted unanimously to raise the interest rates on required and excess reserve balances to 2.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The Fed expects higher inflation so they are likely to increase interest rates.\n    \n    \\item ``Labor productivity has continued to rise over recent months, supporting stronger economic growth and reducing inflationary pressures.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The increase in labor productivity can ease inflation concerns without requiring tighter monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The U.S. trade deficit has widened significantly due to increased imports from foreign nations, contributing to upward pressure on inflation.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: A growing trade deficit can fuel inflation, prompting the Fed to consider tightening monetary policy to control price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``Real GDP was anticipated to increase at a rate noticeably below its potential in 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Expected GDP below potential indicates that economy is slowing down, requiring expansionary monetary policy to prevent any drawbacks.\n\n\n    \\item ``It was agreed that the next meeting of the committee would be held on Tuesday-Wednesday, April 26-27, 2016.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence solely provides scheduling information and does not offer any insights into a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{The Federal Open Market Committee}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & When inflation increases, when unemployment decreases, when economic growth is projected high, when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output, when economic slack falls. & When inflation decreases, when unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Dollar Value Change} &
